elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Hydrothermal reaction of a metal nitrate, a methyl-substituted aliphatic dicarboxylic acid, and the hydrogen-bonding capable 4,4'-dipyridylamine (dpa) ligand afforded four crystalline coordination polymers whose dimensionality, topology, and interpenetration scheme depends on the aliphatic tether length, methyl group position, and coordination geometry at the metal. The four new phases were structurally characterized via single-crystal X-ray diffraction. [Zn(22dmg)(dpa)] n  (1, 22dmg = 2,2-dimethylglutarate) displays a system of mutually inclined interpenetrated (4,4) grid coordination polymer layers. [Zn(33dmg)(dpa)] n  (2, 33dmg = 3,3-dimethylglutarate), in contrast to 1, displays a stacked arrangement of pairs of (4,4) grid coordination polymer layers, without any interpenetration. [Zn(3mad)(dpa)] n  (3, 3mad = 3-methyladipate) possesses a system of four-fold interpenetrated 66 dia topology coordination polymer networks. [Cd(33dmg)(dpa)] n  (4) displays a 2-fold interpenetrated 41263 pcu 3D topology, based on pillaring of dimer-based [Cd2(33dmg)2] n  layers by pairs of dpa ligands. Luminescent behavior in 1-4 is attributed to intra-ligand molecular orbital transitions within the dpa aromatic pyridyl rings. The new phases were also surveyed for the ability to detect nitroaromatics in ethanol suspension, with 4 providing optimum response for nitrobenzene detection. Thermal decomposition behavior is also discussed herein.

elements.clean_text:
Zinc and cadmium aliphatic coordination polymers with 4,4'-dipyridylamine.

Mutual inclined, 4-fold dia, and 2-fold pcu interpenetrated topologies.

"turn-off" luminescence detection of nitroaromatics in ethanol suspension.

Introduction

One of the main thrusts in basic inorganic chemistry research over the past two decades has been the synthesis and structural characterization of divalent metal coordination polymers. These materials have enticing properties in gas separations , supramolecular recognition , anti-bacterial capability , heterogeneous catalysis , and as sensors for the detection of nitroaromatic contaminants . Among the most popular ligand choices for the linkage of divalent metal ions into extended network phases are aromatic dicarboxylates such as terephthalate (1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) , isophthalate (1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) , and phthalate (1,2-benzenedicarboxylate)  with neutral dipyridyl type coligands such as 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) providing connectivity into higher dimensionalities. For instance, the interpenetrated 3D material [Zn2(terephthalate)2(bpy)] n  exhibits an ability to separate linear from branched alkanes when employed as a gas chromatographic stationary phase . Unlike the 3D terephthalate phase, {[Zn(isophthalate)(bpy)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O} n  adopts a simple 2D layer structure . Use of the kinked and hydrogen-bonding capable dipyridyl coligand 4,4'-dipyridylamine (dpa,  ) can provide access to intriguing topologies dramatically different from those observed if the straight rigid-rod pillar bpy is employed. For example, {[Cu2(pht)2(dpa)]⋅H2O} n  manifests homochiral septuple left-handed [Cu2O2(dpa)] n  helices formed by copper ions, phthalate oxygen atoms, and dpa ligands. The septuple helices are bracketed by pht anions to construct chiral nanobarrels with solvent-free channels. . Meanwhile the bpy derivative {[Cu(pht)(bpy)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O} n  forms a standard (4,4) grid layer coordination polymer motif that lacks any multinuclear units .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Less commonly employed in coordination polymer chemistry than the aromatic dicarboxylates are conformationally flexible aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands such as glutarate (glu, 1,5-pentanedicarboxylate) and adipate (adp, 1,6-hexanedicarboxylate). Our group has prepared several new phases containing divalent metal aliphatic dicarboxylates with the kinked dpa ligand . For example, {[Zn(adp)(dpa)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> possesses an mutually inclined interpenentrated system of parallel graphitic (6,3) layer motifs , and [Cd(glu)(dpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> shows a two-fold interpenetrated 4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> network formed by the dpa pillaring of [Cd(glu)]<ce:inf loc="post">

elements.clean_text: Less commonly employed in coordination polymer chemistry than the aromatic dicarboxylates are conformationally flexible aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands such as glutarate (glu, 1,5-pentanedicarboxylate) and adipate (adp, 1,6-hexanedicarboxylate). Our group has prepared several new phases containing divalent metal aliphatic dicarboxylates with the kinked dpa ligand . For example, {[Zn(adp)(dpa)]⋅H2O} n  possesses an mutually inclined interpenentrated system of parallel graphitic (6,3) layer motifs , and [Cd(glu)(dpa)] n  shows a two-fold interpenetrated 41263 pcu network formed by the dpa pillaring of [Cd(glu)] n  dimer-based layers .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In this contribution we have attempted to expand the structural scope of this class of dpa-containing materials by employing methyl-substituted aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands such as 2,2-dimethylglutarate (22dmg, ), 3,3-dimethylglutarate (33dmg, ), and 3-methyladipate (3mad, ). The presence of the methyl group substitution is forecast to impart changes in coordination polymer topology as compared to the unsubstituted aliphatic ligand analogues . We have chosen to focus on zinc and cadmium derivatives, because of their open visible light spectral window predicated on the closed-shell <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> electronic configurations . This can permit visible light emission upon ultraviolet excitation of electrons within the molecular orbital manifolds of the dpa pyridyl rings, and potential “turn-off” sensor behavior for the detection of nitroaromatic explosives trace residues. Herein we report the synthesis, single-crystal structures, topological chemistry, and thermal property determinations of the four new coordination polymer phases [Zn(22dmg)(dpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Zn(33dmg)(dpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Zn(3mad)(dpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), and [Cd(33dmg)(dpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). All four new materials have been assayed for nitroaromatic detecting capability in ethanol suspension.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this contribution we have attempted to expand the structural scope of this class of dpa-containing materials by employing methyl-substituted aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands such as 2,2-dimethylglutarate (22dmg, ), 3,3-dimethylglutarate (33dmg, ), and 3-methyladipate (3mad, ). The presence of the methyl group substitution is forecast to impart changes in coordination polymer topology as compared to the unsubstituted aliphatic ligand analogues . We have chosen to focus on zinc and cadmium derivatives, because of their open visible light spectral window predicated on the closed-shell d 10 electronic configurations . This can permit visible light emission upon ultraviolet excitation of electrons within the molecular orbital manifolds of the dpa pyridyl rings, and potential "turn-off" sensor behavior for the detection of nitroaromatic explosives trace residues. Herein we report the synthesis, single-crystal structures, topological chemistry, and thermal property determinations of the four new coordination polymer phases [Zn(22dmg)(dpa)] n  (1), [Zn(33dmg)(dpa)] n  (2), [Zn(3mad)(dpa)] n  (3), and [Cd(33dmg)(dpa)] n  (4). All four new materials have been assayed for nitroaromatic detecting capability in ethanol suspension.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0030">Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0035">General considerations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Cadmium nitrate and zinc nitrate and the dicarboxylic acids were commercially obtained. The 4,4′-dipyridylamine (dpa) ligand was prepared via a literature procedure . Water was deionized above 3 MΩ–cm in-house. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin Elmer Spectrum One DRIFT instrument. The luminescence spectra were obtained with a Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence Spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Instruments Q-50 Thermogravimetric Analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 600 °C. Elemental Analysis was carried out using a Perkin Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O Analyzer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

General considerations

Cadmium nitrate and zinc nitrate and the dicarboxylic acids were commercially obtained. The 4,4'-dipyridylamine (dpa) ligand was prepared via a literature procedure . Water was deionized above 3MΩ-cm in-house. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin Elmer Spectrum One DRIFT instrument. The luminescence spectra were obtained with a Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence Spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Instruments Q-50 Thermogravimetric Analyzer with a heating rate of 10°C/min up to 600°C. Elemental Analysis was carried out using a Perkin Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O Analyzer.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0060">Nitrobenzene detection studies</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Suspensions of 5 mg ground samples of coordination polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were made in 5 mL ethanol in volumetric flasks, with immersion in an ultrasonic bath for 60 s to ensure an even dispersion. The fluorescence spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> in suspension were recorded with an excitation wavelength of 300 nm. A stock solution of nitrobenzene or <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-nitrophenol (1 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">–4</ce:sup> M) in dimethyl sulfoxide was prepared. Aliquots of this stock solution (10 μL) were added sequentially to ethanol suspensions of the coordination polymers with sonication for 30 s after each addition. The emission spectra were measured before any analyte addition and after each aliquot of analyte solution. The coordination polymers were recovered from these experiments, and washed with ethanol and acetone. Unit cell determinations on the recovered crystalline samples matched with those obtained from their respective original crystal structure determinations.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Nitrobenzene detection studies

Suspensions of 5mg ground samples of coordination polymers 1-4 were made in 5mL ethanol in volumetric flasks, with immersion in an ultrasonic bath for 60s to ensure an even dispersion. The fluorescence spectra of 1-4 in suspension were recorded with an excitation wavelength of 300nm. A stock solution of nitrobenzene or m-nitrophenol (1×10-4 M) in dimethyl sulfoxide was prepared. Aliquots of this stock solution (10μL) were added sequentially to ethanol suspensions of the coordination polymers with sonication for 30s after each addition. The emission spectra were measured before any analyte addition and after each aliquot of analyte solution. The coordination polymers were recovered from these experiments, and washed with ethanol and acetone. Unit cell determinations on the recovered crystalline samples matched with those obtained from their respective original crystal structure determinations.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0065">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Diffraction data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were collected on a Bruker-AXS SMART-CCD X-ray diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 173 K. The data were processed via SAINT , and subjected for Lorentz and polarization effect and absorption corrections using SADABS . The structures were solved using direct methods with SHELXTL  within the OLEX2 crystallographic software suite . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The crystal of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was non-merohedrally twinned. Data from both twin components were used in the final refinements. The crystal of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was also non-merohedrally twinned, but only data from the major twin component was used in the final refinements. The twin laws were determined using CELL NOW . The crystal structure for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> could only be successfully solved and refined in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> as an inversion twin. Disordered ligands were modeled successfully with partial occupancies where present. Crystallographic details for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are given in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Diffraction data for 1-4 were collected on a Bruker-AXS SMART-CCD X-ray diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) at 173K. The data were processed via SAINT , and subjected for Lorentz and polarization effect and absorption corrections using SADABS . The structures were solved using direct methods with SHELXTL  within the OLEX2 crystallographic software suite . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The crystal of 1 was non-merohedrally twinned. Data from both twin components were used in the final refinements. The crystal of 2 was also non-merohedrally twinned, but only data from the major twin component was used in the final refinements. The twin laws were determined using CELL NOW . The crystal structure for 4 could only be successfully solved and refined in the orthorhombic space group P212121 as an inversion twin. Disordered ligands were modeled successfully with partial occupancies where present. Crystallographic details for 1-4 are given in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0070">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0075">Synthesis and spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Crystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were produced by the hydrothermal reaction of the requisite metal nitrate, the requisite dicarboxylic acid, and dpa in the presence of aqueous base. The infrared spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were consistent with their structural components as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Intense, broadened asymmetric and symmetric C–O stretching bands within the carboxylate ligands were observed at 1513 and 1342 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, at 1514 and 1347 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, at 1521 and 1351 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and at 1563 and 1358 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Medium intensity bands in the range of ~ 1600 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> to ~ 1300 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> were ascribed to stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of the dipyridylamide ligands . Features corresponding to C–H bending and ring puckering within the pyridyl moieties exist in the region between ~ 900 and ~ 650 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and spectra

Crystalline samples of 1-4 were produced by the hydrothermal reaction of the requisite metal nitrate, the requisite dicarboxylic acid, and dpa in the presence of aqueous base. The infrared spectra of 1-4 were consistent with their structural components as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Intense, broadened asymmetric and symmetric C-O stretching bands within the carboxylate ligands were observed at 1513 and 1342cm-1 for 1, at 1514 and 1347cm-1 for 2, at 1521 and 1351cm-1 for 3, and at 1563 and 1358cm-1 for 4. Medium intensity bands in the range of ~1600cm-1 to ~1300cm-1 were ascribed to stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of the dipyridylamide ligands . Features corresponding to C-H bending and ring puckering within the pyridyl moieties exist in the region between ~900 and ~650cm-1.

The coordination environment at zinc is a {ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} distorted tetrahedron, with pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two dpa ligands and carboxylate oxygen donor atoms from two 22dmg ligands (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>
a). Bond lengths and angles within the coordination environment are listed in . Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the acentric monoclinic space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2 with a Flack parameter of 0.114(14) indicating a small amount of racemic twinning in the crystal .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural description of [Zn(22dmg)(dpa)] n  (1)

The asymmetric unit of compound 1 contains a divalent zinc atom, a dianionic 22dmg ligand, and a dpa ligand. The coordination environment at zinc is a {ZnN2O2} distorted tetrahedron, with pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two dpa ligands and carboxylate oxygen donor atoms from two 22dmg ligands ( a). Bond lengths and angles within the coordination environment are listed in . Compound 1 crystallizes in the acentric monoclinic space group C2 with a Flack parameter of 0.114(14) indicating a small amount of racemic twinning in the crystal .

elements.clean_text: Bis(monodentate) 22dmg ligands connect the divalent zinc atoms into [Zn(22dmg)] n  chains that are oriented along the [1    1  ̅   0] direction, with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 9.267(2) Å. The 22dmg ligands have a gauche-anti conformation of their five-carbon aliphatic chain (torsion angles=69.8°, 170.3°) In turn these are pillared into [Zn(22dmg)(dpa)] n  (4,4) coordination polymer grids (b) by tethering dipodal dpa ligands that span a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 11.158(3) Å, which represents the c lattice parameter. The rhomboid apertures within the coordination polymer grid motifs have Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn angles of 82.4° and 97.6°, and have through-space Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances of 13.525Å by 15.422Å. The aperture windows allow mutual inclined interpenetration of two parallel sets of [Zn(22dmg)(dpa)] n  layers ( ), at an angle of 66.7° as calculated by TOPOS . Inclined interpenetrated layers are held to each other by hydrogen bonding between dpa amine groups and 22dmg carboxylate oxygen atoms ().

Structural description of [Zn(3mad)(dpa)] n  (3)

The asymmetric unit of compound 3 contains a divalent zinc atom, a dianionic 3mad ligand, and a dpa ligand. The coordination environment at zinc is a {ZnN2O2} distorted tetrahedron, with pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two dpa ligands and carboxylate oxygen donor atoms from two 3mad ligands ( a). Bond lengths and angles within the coordination environment are listed in . Compound 3 crystallizes in the acentric orthorhombic space group Pna21 with a Flack parameter of 0.016(10) indicating virtually complete racemic purity within the crystal .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0095">Structural description of [Cd(33dmg)(dpa)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (4)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">The very large asymmetric unit of compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> contains eight crystallographically distinct cadmium atoms, eight crystallographically distinct 33dmg ligands with slightly different conformations and different disorder components, and eight crystallographically distinct dpa ligands. Of the eight distinct cadmium atoms, with a maximum defined bond length of 2.6 Å, six show a {CdN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} distorted octahedral geometry, with trans pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two dpa ligands in the nominal axial positions. The equatorial positions are taken up by a chelating carboxylate group from one 33dmg ligand and single carboxylate oxygen donor atoms from two other 33dmg ligands. Two cadmium coordination environments show a {CdN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>} pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, again with trans pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two dpa ligands in the nominal axial positions. The equatorial positions are filled by chelating carboxylate groups from two 33dmg ligands, and a single carboxylate oxygen atom donor from a third 33dmg ligand. A representation of one octahedral and one pentagonal bipyramidal coordination environment is shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>
. Bond lengths and angles within the coordination spheres in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are listed in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural description of [Cd(33dmg)(dpa)] n  (4)

The very large asymmetric unit of compound 4 contains eight crystallographically distinct cadmium atoms, eight crystallographically distinct 33dmg ligands with slightly different conformations and different disorder components, and eight crystallographically distinct dpa ligands. Of the eight distinct cadmium atoms, with a maximum defined bond length of 2.6Å, six show a {CdN2O4} distorted octahedral geometry, with trans pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two dpa ligands in the nominal axial positions. The equatorial positions are taken up by a chelating carboxylate group from one 33dmg ligand and single carboxylate oxygen donor atoms from two other 33dmg ligands. Two cadmium coordination environments show a {CdN2O5} pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, again with trans pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two dpa ligands in the nominal axial positions. The equatorial positions are filled by chelating carboxylate groups from two 33dmg ligands, and a single carboxylate oxygen atom donor from a third 33dmg ligand. A representation of one octahedral and one pentagonal bipyramidal coordination environment is shown in  . Bond lengths and angles within the coordination spheres in 4 are listed in .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0110" view="all">In compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, two of the 33dmg ligands (33dmg-A type) adopt an exotetradentate μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>-O,O′:O′:O′′:O′′′ binding mode (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>
) in which one carboxylate terminus chelates to a cadmium atom and provides a single oxygen donor atom to a second cadmium atom, and the other carboxylate end group acts as a bridging group between a third and fourth cadmium atom. All the oxygen atoms of the 33dmg-A ligands bind to cadmium atoms. Half of the 33dmg-A ligands have methyl group positional disorder. Two of the 33dmg ligands (33dmg-B type) adopt an exotetradentate μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-O:O:O′:O′′ binding mode () in which one carboxylate terminus supplies a single oxygen atom that bridges two cadmium atoms, and the other carboxylate end group acts as a bridging group between a third and fourth cadmium atom. One of the oxygen atoms in the 33dmg-B ligands remains unligated. Four of the 33dmg ligands (33dmg-C type) adopt a simple bis(chelating) μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-O,O′:O′′,O′′′ binding mode () that connect two cadmium atoms. All of the 33dmg-C type ligands have an <ce:italic>anti-anti</ce:italic> conformation of their aliphatic tethers, and span Cd···Cd distances of 10.34–10.44 Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In compound 4, two of the 33dmg ligands (33dmg-A type) adopt an exotetradentate μ4-κ5-O,O':O':O'':O''' binding mode ( ) in which one carboxylate terminus chelates to a cadmium atom and provides a single oxygen donor atom to a second cadmium atom, and the other carboxylate end group acts as a bridging group between a third and fourth cadmium atom. All the oxygen atoms of the 33dmg-A ligands bind to cadmium atoms. Half of the 33dmg-A ligands have methyl group positional disorder. Two of the 33dmg ligands (33dmg-B type) adopt an exotetradentate μ4-κ4-O:O:O':O'' binding mode () in which one carboxylate terminus supplies a single oxygen atom that bridges two cadmium atoms, and the other carboxylate end group acts as a bridging group between a third and fourth cadmium atom. One of the oxygen atoms in the 33dmg-B ligands remains unligated. Four of the 33dmg ligands (33dmg-C type) adopt a simple bis(chelating) μ2-κ4-O,O':O'',O''' binding mode () that connect two cadmium atoms. All of the 33dmg-C type ligands have an anti-anti conformation of their aliphatic tethers, and span Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distances of 10.34-10.44Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0115" view="all">In <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, two different [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(33dmg)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">

In the other layer motif (layer-B, b), 33dmg-B type ligands form chain motifs, also with embedded {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O)(OCO)} dimeric units (Cd···Cd distances = 3.892(1) and 3.960(1) Å), pillared into forming 2D layer-B motifs by bis(chelating) 33dmg-C type ligands. The layer-A motifs are pillared by dpa ligands to construct a 3D [Cd(33dmg)(dpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">

a), with the dpa ligands spanning Cd···Cd distances of ~ 12.3 Å. The net-A and net-B motifs weave through each other to give a 2-fold interpenetrated network in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (b). If the {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O)(OCO)} dimeric units are considered 6-connected nodes, the resulting topology is that of a 2-fold interpenetrated 4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> network (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>
). Hydrogen bonding donation between dpa amine groups and 33dmg carboxylate oxygen atoms acts to provide the necessary supramolecular contacts ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In 4, two different [Cd2(33dmg)2] n  layer motifs are formed, depending on which type of 33dmg ligand is involved in bridging the relevant cadmium atoms. In one layer motif (layer-A,  a), 33dmg-A type ligands form chain motifs with embedded {Cd2(O)(OCO)} dimeric units (Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distances=3.891(1) and 3.902(1) Å, pillared into forming layer-A motifs by bis(chelating) 33dmg-C type ligands. In the other layer motif (layer-B, b), 33dmg-B type ligands form chain motifs, also with embedded {Cd2(O)(OCO)} dimeric units (Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distances=3.892(1) and 3.960(1) Å), pillared into forming 2D layer-B motifs by bis(chelating) 33dmg-C type ligands. The layer-A motifs are pillared by dpa ligands to construct a 3D [Cd(33dmg)(dpa)] n  coordination polymer network (net-A), with the dpa ligands spanning Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distances of ~12.3Å. Similarly, the layer-B motifs are pillared by dpa ligands to construct another 3D [Cd(33dmg)(dpa)] n  coordination polymer network (net-B,  a), with the dpa ligands spanning Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distances of ~12.3Å. The net-A and net-B motifs weave through each other to give a 2-fold interpenetrated network in 4 (b). If the {Cd2(O)(OCO)} dimeric units are considered 6-connected nodes, the resulting topology is that of a 2-fold interpenetrated 41263 pcu network ( ). Hydrogen bonding donation between dpa amine groups and 33dmg carboxylate oxygen atoms acts to provide the necessary supramolecular contacts ().

Organic ligand combustion occurred above ~ 225 °C. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibited a stable mass until ~ 320 °C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. elements.clean_text:
Thermal properties of 1-4

Compound 1 exhibited a stable mass until ~215°C, whereupon one molar equivalent of CO2 was purged due to decarboxylation (10.1% obs'd, 11.1% calc'd). Organic ligand combustion occurred above ~225°C. Compound 2 exhibited a stable mass until ~320°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. Compound 2 exhibited a stable mass until ~320°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. Compound 3 exhibited a stable mass until ~200°C, whereupon decarboxylation commenced. This mass loss was complete by ~320°C, with a total mass loss of 10.1% matching roughly with the calculated value of 11.1% for one molar equivalent of CO2. Ligand combustion occurred above ~320°C. Compound 4 exhibited a stable mass until ~315°C, whereupon full ligand combustion occurred. TGA traces for 1-4 are shown in , respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0105">Luminescent properties of 1–4</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">Polycrystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> in ethanol suspension were irradiated with ultraviolet light in order to investigate their capability for photoluminescence. Excitation spectra were first obtained in order to determine the optimum wavelength for photoluminescent excitation, via monitoring emission at a single wavelength of 400 nm. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the maximum excitation was observed at 310 nm, 320 nm, 300 nm, and 280 nm respectively. Broad and modestly intense violet light emission profiles were observed in all cases (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>
), with maximum emission wavelengths at 342 nm, 349 nm, 347 nm, and 344 nm respectively for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. All spectral profiles showed tail features into the violet region of the visible spectrum. It is most plausible that the fluorescent behavior of these materials can be attributed to π–π* or π–<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> molecular orbital transitions within the pyridyl rings of the dipyridylamine ligands , as the aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands lack any π bonding and should not absorb ultraviolet light.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties of 1-4

Polycrystalline samples of 1-4 in ethanol suspension were irradiated with ultraviolet light in order to investigate their capability for photoluminescence. Excitation spectra were first obtained in order to determine the optimum wavelength for photoluminescent excitation, via monitoring emission at a single wavelength of 400nm. For 1-4, the maximum excitation was observed at 310nm, 320nm, 300nm, and 280nm respectively. Broad and modestly intense violet light emission profiles were observed in all cases ( ), with maximum emission wavelengths at 342nm, 349nm, 347nm, and 344nm respectively for 1-4. All spectral profiles showed tail features into the violet region of the visible spectrum. It is most plausible that the fluorescent behavior of these materials can be attributed to π-π* or π-n molecular orbital transitions within the pyridyl rings of the dipyridylamine ligands , as the aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands lack any π bonding and should not absorb ultraviolet light.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0110">Nitroaromatic detection properties of 1–4</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were assayed for capability as “turn-off” nitroaromatic detectors in ethanol suspension. As seen in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>
, the emission signal for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> decreased as micromolar amounts of nitrobenzene (NB) in DMSO were added, revealing “turn-off” sensor behavior. By addition of 100 μL of a 1.0 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">–4</ce:sup> M solution of NB in DMSO, the emission of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was virtually extinguished. Compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> also showed capability for “turn-off” sensor behavior (, respectively). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> also exhibited “turn-off” sensor behavior for the detection of <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-nitrophenol (NP), as seen in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0065"></ce:float-anchor>
. The decrease in emission intensity in all cases is ascribed to electron transfer to the molecular orbitals of the electron deficient nitroaromatic analyte from the excited states of dpa pyridyl ring aromatic orbitals in the coordination polymer framework .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Nitroaromatic detection properties of 1-4

Compounds 1-4 were assayed for capability as "turn-off" nitroaromatic detectors in ethanol suspension. As seen in  , the emission signal for compound 1 decreased as micromolar amounts of nitrobenzene (NB) in DMSO were added, revealing "turn-off" sensor behavior. By addition of 100μL of a 1.0×10-4 M solution of NB in DMSO, the emission of compound 1 was virtually extinguished. Compounds 2-4 also showed capability for "turn-off" sensor behavior (, respectively). Compound 1 also exhibited "turn-off" sensor behavior for the detection of m-nitrophenol (NP), as seen in  . The decrease in emission intensity in all cases is ascribed to electron transfer to the molecular orbitals of the electron deficient nitroaromatic analyte from the excited states of dpa pyridyl ring aromatic orbitals in the coordination polymer framework .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0135" view="all">To quantify the absorption behavior, the emission data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> in the presence of nitroaromatic analytes were analyzed using the Stern-Volmer equation , <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>0</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>/I</ce:italic> = <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">sv</ce:inf>[A] + 1, where <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>0</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> is the initial emission intensity in the absence of analyte, <ce:italic>I</ce:italic> is the emission intensity in the presence of analyte, [A] is the molarity of analyte, and <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">sv</ce:inf> is the Stern-Volmer quenching constant. The <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">sv</ce:inf> values are listed in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>
, and plots are shown in . From the respective <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">sv</ce:inf> values for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in the presence of NB and NP, it can be seen that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a preferential absorption of the less sterically bulky NB analyte as opposed to the sterically bulkier NP analyte. It is plausible that the regions between inclined interpenetrated layers in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can accommodate the inclusion of nitroaromatic analytes. However, it is likely that the phenolic substituent retards absorption of NP into the coordination polymer matrix of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in comparison to NB. The closely stacked layer motifs in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and the four-fold interpenetrated coordination polymer networks in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> do not permit as much absorption of analyte, although these compounds do act as “turn-off” sensors for NB. Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> showed the optimum absorption of NB, as the two-fold interpenetrated network allows access of the NB analyte into close enough proximity to the dpa pyridyl rings to permit excimer electron transfer to occur.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To quantify the absorption behavior, the emission data for 1-4 in the presence of nitroaromatic analytes were analyzed using the Stern-Volmer equation , I  0  /I=K sv[A]+1, where I  0  is the initial emission intensity in the absence of analyte, I is the emission intensity in the presence of analyte, [A] is the molarity of analyte, and K sv is the Stern-Volmer quenching constant. The K sv values are listed in  , and plots are shown in . From the respective K sv values for 1 in the presence of NB and NP, it can be seen that compound 1 shows a preferential absorption of the less sterically bulky NB analyte as opposed to the sterically bulkier NP analyte. It is plausible that the regions between inclined interpenetrated layers in 1 can accommodate the inclusion of nitroaromatic analytes. However, it is likely that the phenolic substituent retards absorption of NP into the coordination polymer matrix of 1 in comparison to NB. The closely stacked layer motifs in 2 and the four-fold interpenetrated coordination polymer networks in 3 do not permit as much absorption of analyte, although these compounds do act as "turn-off" sensors for NB. Compound 4 showed the optimum absorption of NB, as the two-fold interpenetrated network allows access of the NB analyte into close enough proximity to the dpa pyridyl rings to permit excimer electron transfer to occur.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0115">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0140" view="all">A series of coordination polymers based on methyl-substituted aliphatic dicarboxylate and the hydrogen-bonding capable dipyridylamine ligand has been prepared and characterized, and shows wide ranging topological diversity. Two of the derivatives, the zinc 2,2-dimethylglutarate and 3,3-dimethylglutarate dpa complexes, show (4,4) grid motifs. However the former exhibited mutually inclined interpenetration and the latter manifested closely-stacked bilayer slabs. The longer 3-methyladipate ligand afforded a four-fold interpenetrated <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> topology zinc coordination polymer in the presence of dpa. Due to an increase in ionic radius at the metal ion and resultant higher coordination number, the cadmium 3,3-dimethylglutarate dpa derivative displayed a two-fold interpenetrated dimer-based <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> network. While all four new materials capably served as “turn-off” sensors for the detection of nitrobenzene upon irradiation with ultraviolet light, the cadmium 3,3-dimethylglutarate dpa derivative provided optimum detection performance.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of coordination polymers based on methyl-substituted aliphatic dicarboxylate and the hydrogen-bonding capable dipyridylamine ligand has been prepared and characterized, and shows wide ranging topological diversity. Two of the derivatives, the zinc 2,2-dimethylglutarate and 3,3-dimethylglutarate dpa complexes, show (4,4) grid motifs. However the former exhibited mutually inclined interpenetration and the latter manifested closely-stacked bilayer slabs. The longer 3-methyladipate ligand afforded a four-fold interpenetrated dia topology zinc coordination polymer in the presence of dpa. Due to an increase in ionic radius at the metal ion and resultant higher coordination number, the cadmium 3,3-dimethylglutarate dpa derivative displayed a two-fold interpenetrated dimer-based pcu network. While all four new materials capably served as "turn-off" sensors for the detection of nitrobenzene upon irradiation with ultraviolet light, the cadmium 3,3-dimethylglutarate dpa derivative provided optimum detection performance.

Preparation of [Zn(22dmg)(dpa)] n  (1)

Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (83mg, 0.28mmol), dpa (48mg, 0.28mmol), and 2,2-dimethylglutaric acid (62mg, 0.28mmol) were mixed with 10mL of distilled H2O and 0.55mL of 1M NaOH in a 23mL Teflon-lined acid digestion bomb. <ce:section-title id="sect0100">Thermal properties of 1–4</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibited a stable mass until ~ 215 °C, whereupon one molar equivalent of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was purged due to decarboxylation (10.1% obs’d, 11.1% calc’d). Organic ligand combustion occurred above ~ 225 °C. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibited a stable mass until ~ 320 °C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibited a stable mass until ~ 320 °C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibited a stable mass until ~ 200 °C, whereupon decarboxylation commenced. This mass loss was complete by ~ 320 °C, with a total mass loss of 10.1% matching roughly with the calculated value of 11.1% for one molar equivalent of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Ligand combustion occurred above ~ 320 °C. Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> exhibited a stable mass until ~ 315 °C, whereupon full ligand combustion occurred. TGA traces for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are shown in , respectively.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0105">Luminescent properties of 1–4</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">Polycrystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> in ethanol suspension were irradiated with ultraviolet light in order to investigate their capability for photoluminescence. Excitation spectra were first obtained in order to determine the optimum wavelength for photoluminescent excitation, via monitoring emission at a single wavelength of 400 nm. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the maximum excitation was observed at 310 nm, 320 nm, 300 nm, and 280 nm respectively. Broad and modestly intense violet light emission profiles were observed in all cases (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>
), with maximum emission wavelengths at 342 nm, 349 nm, 347 nm, and 344 nm respectively for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. All spectral profiles showed tail features into the violet region of the visible spectrum. It is most plausible that the fluorescent behavior of these materials can be attributed to π–π* or π–<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> molecular orbital transitions within the pyridyl rings of the dipyridylamine ligands , as the aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands lack any π bonding and should not absorb ultraviolet light.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal properties of 1-4

Compound 1 exhibited a stable mass until ~215°C, whereupon one molar equivalent of CO2 was purged due to decarboxylation (10.1% obs'd, 11.1% calc'd). Organic ligand combustion occurred above ~225°C. Compound 2 exhibited a stable mass until ~320°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. Compound 2 exhibited a stable mass until ~320°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. Compound 3 exhibited a stable mass until ~200°C, whereupon decarboxylation commenced. This mass loss was complete by ~320°C, with a total mass loss of 10.1% matching roughly with the calculated value of 11.1% for one molar equivalent of CO2. Ligand combustion occurred above ~320°C. Compound 4 exhibited a stable mass until ~315°C, whereupon full ligand combustion occurred. TGA traces for 1-4 are shown in , respectively.

Luminescent properties of 1-4

Polycrystalline samples of 1-4 in ethanol suspension were irradiated with ultraviolet light in order to investigate their capability for photoluminescence. Excitation spectra were first obtained in order to determine the optimum wavelength for photoluminescent excitation, via monitoring emission at a single wavelength of 400nm. For 1-4, the maximum excitation was observed at 310nm, 320nm, 300nm, and 280nm respectively. Broad and modestly intense violet light emission profiles were observed in all cases ( ), with maximum emission wavelengths at 342nm, 349nm, 347nm, and 344nm respectively for 1-4. All spectral profiles showed tail features into the violet region of the visible spectrum. It is most plausible that the fluorescent behavior of these materials can be attributed to π-π* or π-n molecular orbital transitions within the pyridyl rings of the dipyridylamine ligands , as the aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands lack any π bonding and should not absorb ultraviolet light.
